reviews.review: As a straight up shooter this game is excellent. When you add in the plasmid mechanics, mindbending storyline, and unique art style this game is above and beyond. Looks excellent and runs smoothly even on the low settings of my laptop.
why.

Bioshock Infinite is American overproportional glory at its finest. it’s beautiful yet deep dark orientated visuals keep you wanting more whilst at the same time you find yourself hiding behind the nearest object trying to avoid the brutal Bioshock plot twists and weird multi-sub contextual climax's. The games beauty is somewhat hindered by the poor combat experience which I feel dominates the Bioshock Franchise; although you don't play this game for the combat it is a tiny but obvious let-down to an otherwise awesome game. 9/10. It’s an almighty power hit to brain, a visually explosion to the senses and a story which would make any psycho-serial killer equally cower and cry over a superb narrative masterpiece.
Überaus atemberaubendes Spiel, was einen Spieler oftmals für Stunden fesselt! Tolle Grafik, tolle Action und eine fesselnde Story die einen öfters Nachdenken lässt! Absolute Kaufempfehlung! LG HB
great game
Захватывающий саундтрек, невероятно динамичный и затягивающий геймплей, очень интересный, лихо закрученный сюжет, шикарная графика - рекомендую всем любителям приключенченских шутеров.    9/10

BioShock Infinite does a good job of hiding a basic [i]non dynamic first person shooter[/i] under a stunning universe flavoured with steampunk and gorgeous visuals and great audio. The role playing portion of the game consist of choosing which [i]paranormal or magic[/i] abilities to upgrade for currency which you pick up while completing the game. The abilities them selves you get as you progress through the game. Unfortunately all the abilities are basically the same and thus I found that portion of the game inferior to its predecessor. If the powers had been left out of the game as they are I wouldn't have missed them. Basically what ever you'll pick wont matter. Weapons can also be upgraded, on normal difficulty atleast you don't need to upgrade anything to complete the game but it does give you mini-goals ingame that keep you interested. Some upgrades change the characteristics of the weapons in entertaining ways. The story is good but nothing special what is good however is the depth of the non-player characters you interact with (in various ways), there are some interesting individuals in the world of BioShock Infinite. I absolutely recomend this game to anyone who enjoys a good single player experience. I just think this game has been greatly overhyped that however doesn't make it a bad game.

I can't even tell you how awesome it was - it was like 10/10, hands down. I think BioShock Infinite has one of the best endings ever. It was interesting, it was deep. It left me with this silence. 

What about the graphics?
Well, the game is one of the best looking games on PC right now (2014-02), so you got to understand that this game looks awesome. I even took a screenshot, put it on my wallpaper - it looks like a normal photo! OUTSTANDING!

So my overall rating: 10/10 - TOTALLY WORTH IT!!!

A pesar del cambio del gran cambio que da Infinite con sus predecesores, Bioshock Infinite se renueva y crea una atmósfera estética espectacular con la ciudad de Columbia. Una historia alucinante, totalmente inesperada y con multitud de gags y guiños a películas, juegos y demás. Además, con sus DLCs (un poco caros por desgracia) se renueva añadiendo de nuevo una aventura en Rapture y una ampliación grande para Columbia. En definitiva, un briche de lujo para la saga Bioshock
9/10
It's really good if you're picking up what im tossin'.

What is supposed to be a display of the dystopian nature of humanity (there will never be a perfect society) almost entirely loses focus on some sort of religious vendetta, probably stemming from the personal beliefs of the game's director.
The people at Irrational Games came close to providing a story about a fictional world in which all of this could be viewed as satire, but in the end a specific line is drawn and it is made clear that Bioshock Infinite is propaganda material aimed squarely at one religion, and to the exclusion of all others I might add.

This game belongs in the same category as Postal, which is designed to insult as many people as possible. Except where Postal knows what it is and the makers intended nothing less, Bioshock Infinite is just using a sci-fi adventure shell to deliver a defamatory message.
If they had cut just a single word from the dialogue of the game at one specific point my argument would crumble, we could say it's all fiction and be on our merry way, but obviously they put that one word in to incite this type of response.



On the gameplay front, I have to say I'm not terribly impressed either.
Not to say that what they accomplished isn't an incredibly polished experience, but it's definitely losing the roots of what anything ending in "shock" is supposed to be. Warren Spector is the creator of System Shock, Thief, and Deus Ex. All three follow a similar gameplay theme (stealth, with multipath levels and a focus on player choice), but set in future, past or present (near future) settings.
The original Bioshock was a spiritual successor to that lineage after Warren Spector hadn't produced anything new for a while, but this game loses most of what defines a title in that genre. There is little to no stealth, few choices in how to make your way through a level, and even the upgrades are largely forced on you at specific points in the game. You have the rails, which are fun, but if anything it symbolizes what is happening to the rest of the game. It's turning into the dreaded "rail shooter" that currently floods the industry, which is really ironic since the main selling point of the original was that it is supposed to be anything but a rail shooter. Not to say that you can't make a good one, but again, Irrational Games is selling you on the name and giving you something different.

I recommend Dishonored to those looking for another Warren Spector style game.

So, what's there to say about this game. I'm only 2 hours into the game so far, and I can only say one thing... WOW in terms of graphics and game design, the game uses the same kind of game play as the previous games in the franchise, the shooting feels great, the vigors (kind of magic powers are quite original, although not completely, the crow murder is an equivalent of the bees from the previous games and also reminds me of the rats in Dishonored, but that's not really a bad thing :) ) Technically speaking I dont have a gaming rig (i7 8gb ram, 540m), but the game runs smooth in 720p with all set to normal and aa turned off.
Anyway I'll update the review once I get into the game more. So far I deffinetly recommend the game.

This game is ferocious in its pride as a shooter, which is drastically outweighed by its proud ferocity in being a deep, complex, story driven game. Bioshock Infinite is a brilliant yet fantastical adventure that will take you through sprawling heavenlike cities littered with false propogander, and down into the dark, withdrawn areas which are smothered in desperality. This game is a true master peice featuring beautiful scores and mind blowing sites. Irrational Games have truly outdone themselves this time, and with just under 20 hours of gameplay in the bag I can safely say whether i'm in the train or i'm on the toilet, I will never forget this game. 10/10

If you're looking for a game with a story intensity to match it's gameplay, then Bioshock infinite is the game for you. Bioshock Infinite provides an engaging play style very unique from your typical first person shooters, mixed together with it's unique textures for backgrounds and characters, it's certainly a game where you can truly admire how much work has been put into it. To top the stunning textures and settings, the story provides players with a sympathetic and empathetic overview of the characters as they follow the protagonist Booker Dewitt and Elizabeth on their Journey to find out the truth about the flying city of Columbia. Thi intense and engaging storyline will hook players much like many oscar winning films would, by placing them on the edge of their seats. So if you're looking to play a masterpiece of a game, unique in its own kind, Bioshock Infinite is the perfect game for you.

While the game excels in artistic design and visuals, it unfortunately falls a little flat in gameplay. Many mechanics from previous entries to the series have been simplified to the point where most aspects of character building and progression have been lost, resulting in a traditional first-person shooter. Many of the enemies feel anonymous or unimportant, and the level design seems to consist largely of arenas where enemies are fought and corridors that connect them.

In spite of the bland gameplay, the art design is nothing less than beautiful. Colors are vibrant and radiant, and truly serve to convey the theme of early twentieth century American Exceptionalism taken to extreme lengths. The city of Columbia is home to some extraordinary scenery, and it's unfortunate that its potential wasn't explored further. The game's narrative is fanciful and grandiose, befitting the setting in which it takes place.

All said, Bioshock Infinite has its high points and low points. It's certainly a game worth looking into, though you may want to wait until the next time it goes on sale.

So much has been put into this game by the creators. 

The abstract and compelling story has an enticing appeal that makes me want to play it over and over. The story is deep on so many levels, I believe this game could have been made into a movie rather than a game.

Gameplay is exciting with dramatic scenes and intense plot "twists".

Combat is subpar, yet still very enjoyable. Fighting baddies in this game gets repetitive and old.

Gun selection is weak. Little variation.

Lovely artwork.

SUMMARY- The story of this game incorporates history, science, morals/ethics and religion all into one intense plot. This game is a MUST PLAY just because of its deep impact it can make on players. The story easily makes up for the variation-lacking combat.

What can I say, this game is simply amazing. The gameplay is leaps over the previous Bioshock games. The weapons are fun to use and the powers (vigors) are even more devilishly wicked in terms of taking on the enemies that the game throws at you. Coming up with combos of the vigors and weapons to use just made it quite compelling and not once felt boring to me. The same can be said about the storyline; it was fascinating, addicting and had me wanting more. The main character Booker DeWitt had a Han Solo vibe happening. And that ending was just heart pounding and had me shocked at how it kept me thinking about it hours and even days later. Hollywood can only dream of coming up with anything original that would come as close to what these game studios are coming up with lately. 

My two year old computer ran the game flawlessly with it looking so incredibly gorgous. The graphics are just breathtaking and beautiful to look at - I was in awe the entire time. I was expecting it to lag with the settings on ultra, but that wasn't the case. Yeah, I love this game and look forward to playing the DLC now. Heck, I may just play through this one again before I tackle them next.

The only downside i could find with this game is that the combat can get kind off monotonous.
But that's the only downside. Bioshock Infinite was 2013's best story driven FPS, hands down. The story will confuse you if you don't pay attention and play through it with an open mind, but that's part of what makes it a great story.
Alongside the story there is the beautifully designed floating city of Columbia and the graphical style of the game will immerse you into it's world. This game is a graphical gem without requiring you to build a €1000 gaming rig.

If you are sick of all the military multiplayer focused shooters that have flooded the FPS genre, then this might be the game for you. Wait for it to go on sale though. ;)

The environment is fantastic, the character and storyline is engaging but the whole somehow doesn't add up to the sum of its parts. Combat is a boring grind, and here is little interaction with the people of Columbia other than fighting them. The vending machines and recordings which were somewhat entertaining in the original Bioshock failed to interest me this time around.

It's still worth playing, but wait until its on sale. I feel that this game was so anticipated, so over-hyped and so long in the making that it was unable to take the real chances with the gameplay that it really needed. Less combat and more adventure next time please, Mr. Levine.

BioShock Infinite is one of those games that sticks with you. Having beat it well over a month ago, I still think quite fondly of it and how the entire game blew my mind. It's atmosphere, graphics, engaging story, balanced and solid gameplay had me coming back for more. It deserves all the praise it gets, and more so. I'm a massive BioShock fan, and an avid player of the original (Which I've beaten numerous times). The second one was a little disappointing for me, but still a solid and well-made game. So when I first picked up Infinite, I was more than a little apprehensive. However, my doubts flew out of my head the instant I started it up. If you're a fan of incredible stories, great first person action, or just love video games, check this one out. It's worth every minute.
